title: Co-Heads  Named for  Warner  Movie  Division  ----  By Robbie Whelan and Joe Flint
text:
Warner Bros. Discovery Inc. named industry veterans Mike De Luca and Pam Abdy as co-heads of Warner Bros. Pictures Group, the company said Wednesday.

Warner Bros. Picture Group Chairman Toby Emmerich is stepping down as a result of the reorganization, led by the newly formed company's Chief Executive David Zaslav. Mr. Emmerich has signed a five-year deal to make movies and television shows at Warner Bros., the company said.

Mr. Zaslav's latest leadership shake-up underscores his aggressive approach to restructuring and slimming down the businesses after his Discovery Inc. combined with WarnerMedia, which had been a unit of AT&T Inc., in a merger that was completed in April. His changes have also been aimed at cutting costs across the company including its cable television networks, including CNN, TNT and TBS.

Mr. Zaslav said in a statement that Mr. De Luca and Ms. Abdy "are supremely talented creative leaders" that can "take this nearly century-old iconic studio to even greater heights of excellence in film."

In a memo to staff Wednesday Mr. Zaslav praised Mr. Emmerich and said he is "thrilled that he has chosen to remain a part of our Warner Bros. Discovery family through this new production venture." Mr. Emmerich will remain in his current role through the summer, Mr. Zaslav said.

Mr. De Luca and Ms. Abdy -- who most recently ran MGM Motion Picture Group -- will have a smaller role than Mr. Emmerich has had. Mr. Emmerich also oversaw DC Films, the movie arm of Warner Bros.' DC Comics unit.

Warner Bros. plans to follow a similar strategy as Walt Disney Co., which breaks out its Marvel Studios superhero franchise into a separate business unit with its own creative executives, rather than having it report to another studio head.

Mr. DeLuca made a splash as a young film executive who championed directors including Paul Thomas Anderson and David Fincher. Mr. DeLuca has played a key role in numerous hit films including "Boogie Nights" and "The Social Network." Ms. Abdy has had her fingerprints on successful movies including Mr. Fincher's "Gone Girl."
